docs.lead_paragraph: The Cradle of Aviation Museum has a deficit of $1.5 million, it has been criticized in an audit by the county comptroller, and its management team has been pressured for months by Nassau County leaders.

headline.print_headline: Suozzi Offers Plan to Shore Up Aviation Museum

docs.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines reached agreements with retirees to reduce health benefits and save the company $50 million a year. The agreements include increased cost-sharing for retirees under age 65, who will have to pay more for subsidized coverage. Nonpilot retirees over 65 will get a $50 monthly subsidy to pay for a plan intended to supplement Medicare. Retired pilots over 65 will also get a subsidy. Delta will create a $2 million hardship fund for those who cannot meet the higher costs. Delta sought to reduce retiree benefits because they were ''among the most generous and costly in the airline industry,'' the carrier said.

headline.main: Today In Business: Delta Cuts Health Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Falling Into the Doughnut Hole'' (editorial, Oct. 6):

headline.main: Who Benefits From the Drug Plan?

docs.abstract: Five letters comment on Oct 6 editorial about Medicare drug program; John E LeMoult says it is one of most repugnant laws passed by Congress; Augustana College Prof Daniel E Lee says it makes sense to provide universal coverage up to certain level of expenditure and catastrophic coverage for those with huge prescription drug costs; Dr Marvin S Wool notes that more than 85 percent of beneficiaries will never reach 'doughnut hole'; George Washington University Medical Center associate vice pres Gerald Bass says feature encourages consumers to be prudent in using drugs; drawing; Lenore Brooks questions why American politicians are against providing universal health plan
